docs.lead_paragraph: Health care spending grew more slowly in 1994 than in any year since 1960, the Government reported today. National health care spending totaled $949.4 billion, or 13.7 percent of total economic output -- the gross domestic product -- in 1994, the Department of Health and Human Services said. The growth in health spending in 1994, 6.4 percent, was "the slowest recorded in more than three decades," it said.

headline.main: Health Costs Are Growing More Slowly, Report Says

docs.lead_paragraph: A chart Saturday about New York City's efforts to shift Medicaid recipients into managed-care plans misidentified the sources of the data. They were the State Department of Health and the State Department of Social Services, not their city counterparts.

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY met at Club Getaway. They became engaged on the stoop of the house they dreamed of buying. They got married in the front parlor of the house -- four months before they bought it. "You see, there was my best friend, and her guy was Marc's best friend growing up," said Dr. Iris Vardy Strauss, a very athletic orthodontist. "At one point, I'd actually been on the Getaway staff -- you know, it's that 'weekend camp for adults' up in Connecticut -- teaching mountain climbing and rollerblading. But one weekend, Memorial Day weekend last year, I was there as just a guest."

headline.main: Habitats/130 West 78th Street;A Couple's New Home Already Houses Memories

docs.lead_paragraph: A front-page article last Sunday, about efforts by states to restrict health plans' cost-cutting practices, referred incorrectly to such laws in Georgia. And a map with the article, summarizing such restrictions nationwide, reflected the error. Georgia's requirement that health plans accept any physician with appropriate credentials applies only to insurer-based "preferred provider" organizations; it does not apply to all health networks.

docs.lead_paragraph: THE role of trustees at private universities on Long Island has drawn attention after press reports of alleged improprieties prompted the state to investigate the president and trustees of Adelphi University. Trustees and officials of other institutions withheld their views about Adelphi, but some said they were following events closely.

headline.main: State's Adelphi Inquiry Raises Larger Questions on Trustees

docs.lead_paragraph: LAURA LOPEZ was at her job at a Greenwich insurance company when the phone rang. Her 78-year-old mother, who shares her Stamford home, was distraught. She had been attacked by their 11-year-old cat, she told Laura. "I asked her if she was all right," Ms. Lopez said. "All she could say was, 'I don't think so.' I asked her what happened and she kept saying she didn't remember."

headline.main: The Elderly In Need of Help

docs.lead_paragraph: DOGS are more and more part of the vacationing family. On the road, you see them using their special exercise spots at rest areas along the highways; in airports, you see the kennels waiting while owners give their dogs a last trot around before boarding. Children often feel it isn't any fun unless the family pet goes along, and parents these days give increasing attention to the needs of the children on vacation. But taking a pet, particularly a larger dog, is not a simple matter. Whether traveling by car or plane, the logistics and safety planning, including reservations, special charges, equipment and providing for meals, can be as complicated as for people.

docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal to help small businesses band together and buy health insurance for their employees at reduced rates, initially greeted with acclaim, is now drawing criticism from state officials and Democratic members of Congress who say it would undermine states' ability to protect consumers against insurance fraud. The dispute is one of several stalling the legislation, the first major effort to expand coverage since the demise of President Clinton's health plan in September 1994. Another major disagreement involves medical savings accounts, which are favored by House Republicans but opposed by Mr. Clinton.

headline.main: HEALTH CARE BILL DRAWS OPPOSITION ON KEY PROVISIONS

docs.lead_paragraph: The psychiatrists are on Cape Cod, the black professionals are in Azurest on Long Island and the Syrian Jews are in Deal on the Jersey shore. A clutch of East Village artists has moved into $60,000 Victorians in the Catskills, and Brooke Astor is at Cove End, her white-shingled "cottage" off the coast of Maine. For many New Yorkers, you are where you summer.

headline.main: It's a Summer Thing;For Like-Minded New Yorkers, a Season of Separation

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re "Questions of Privacy Roil Arena of Psychotherapy" (front page, May 22): Mental health providers who sign up with managed care companies typically enter into contractual arrangements whereby they agree to permit an insurer to review client records periodically. By making a Faustian bargain, it is they -- not the managed care companies -- who betray patient trust.

headline.main: Psychotherapist Has Duty to Maintain Privacy
